title.narrative: Water for Three States (W4TS) - Rural

description.narrative: 350,000 (300,000 direct) people living in Gedaref, Kassala and Red Sea states in Sudan

Specifically the programme will: 1. Establish catchment-level Water Resources Management Committees that represent the key stakeholders, and facilitate the development of catchment-level Water Resources Management Plans through a participatory planning process and through provision of expert input to analyse the feasibility of different options 2. Provide secure access to safe water through renovation and construction of water points and infrastructure for enhancing groundwater recharge, as flowing from the catchment-level Water Resources Management Plans. 3. Promote improvements in hygiene and sanitation practices 4. Document and share lessons learnt within and outside Sudan

This programme will bring sustainable water supplies, improved hygiene and better sanitation practices to 350,000 people living in Gedaref, Kassala and Red Sea states in Sudan. This programme will be implemented by International Aid Services (IAS), Islamic Relief Worldwide (IRW), Plan International, Practical Action, SOS Sahel Sudan and ZOA. ZOA is Consortium Lead and will publish on behalf of the consortium through IATI.

participating-org.narrative: ZOA as Lead Agency for this consortium

title.narrative: Outcome: Sustainable use of water resources and clean drinking water supply, and improved sanitation & hygiene behaviour
Outcome indicator 1: Number of people with sustainable access to clean drinking water sources (disaggregated by state/locality and gender) - DFID standard indicator

comment.narrative: At the time of writing this report this information still had to be verified

By the end of 2017, the Aqua4East partnership has provided sustainable access to clean drinking water sources for 136,950 people. Red Sea State – 68,300 IAS: 19,900 SOS: 48,300 Kassala State – 53,700 PA: 30,000 Plan: 23,700 Gedaref State – 14,950 ZOA: 4,800 IRW: 10,150

title.narrative: Outcome indicator 3: Percentage of people in targeted communities who can fetch water in less than 30 minutes (including travel time, waiting time and time for filling the containers)

comment.narrative: 48% in rainy season; 45% in dry season according to 2016 rainy season survey.
Gedaref: 86% (80% to safe source) Kassala: 89% (61% to safe source) Red Sea: 6% (all to safe source)
KAP survey cancelled due to budget restrictions.

50% (and measurement of trip time verified)
This information will be delivered by the KAP survey, expected by end of February 2018.

title.narrative: Output 4: Action learning to promote replication of IWRM
Number of seminars, fora, and conferences in Sudan and elsewhere at which experiences are shared

comment.narrative: 1. IHSA conference 2. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at a seminar organized by LandAC in Utrecht, the Netherlands on 7 December 2017 3. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at the Planetary Security Conference in The Hague, the Netherlands, on 12-13 December 2017. 4. Participation at ISMAR conference in Madrid (May 2019) 5. Presentation by IWRM Expert on 2nd IWRM Water conference in Sudan organised by UNESCO/UNICEF on 2/3 December 2019. 6. Water Resources Engineer of PCU participated in a Water conference organised by the government on 30 and 31st December 2019. Some of the water harvesting experiences were used in a paper presented during the conference. 7. Head of PCU presented about the IWRM Group coordination at the Water Conference ‘Harnessing the Promise of the Water Sector for a prosperous New Sudan’ on 18th and 19th February 2020, organised by the Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources

1. Project approach and experiences were shared at the WASH sector meeting in Khartoum on 6th September 2. The IWRM conference in Khartoum organized by UNEP and partners on 21-23 November. 3. In Kassala an IWRM conference was organized in November 2017. During this conference an IWRM forum was inaugurated. 4. Participation in the brainstorm sessions on the new WASH strategy for Sudan: IWRM got included on the agenda. 5. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at a seminar organized by LandAC in Utrecht, the Netherlands on 7 December 6. Analysis of climate patterns and their impacts was shared at the Planetary Security Conference in The Hague, the Netherlands, on 12-13 December.
Update Q4 2019.

title.narrative: Number of technical papers produced and shared with relevant stakeholders

comment.narrative: 1. Draft of ‘Putting catchment-level IWRM into practice’ by Bromwich and Gaasbeek 2. Final of ‘Rainfall patterns in the Sahel and their implications for medium-term food security’ by Dr. T.J. Gaasbeek. Update Q4 2019.
1. Putting catchment-level IWRM into practice 6. Mini irrigation scheme: modification spate irrigation in Mesga 7. IWRM and Peace 10. Hygiene & Sanitation manual

title.narrative: Output 3: Behaviour change for improved sanitation and hygiene practices
% change in attitude to sanitation practices, defined as disposing children's faeces in a latrine or covered hole

comment.narrative: Gedaref 51% (+11%) Kassala 65% (-8%) Red Sea 53% (+8%)
KAP 2019 was not conducted due to lack of qualified bidders.
To be reported after KAP 2020 (cancelled)

KAP 2019 was not conducted due to lack of qualified bidders.
To be reported after KAP 2020 (cancelled)

title.narrative: Output 2: Sustainable access to water
Water conservation infrastructure constructed with active management & maintenance

comment.narrative: 10 recharge infrastructures have been rehabilitated or constructed in the 3 States
A total of 61 structures have been completed.
Update Q4 2018.
Update Q4 2019.
feasible locations identified

title.narrative: Number of drinking water points renovated, upgraded and/or constructed with a functioning well-trained WUC

comment.narrative: 120 water points have been renovated, upgraded or constructed in the 3 States: 82 Hand Pumps 12 Mini Water Yards 5 Handdug Wells 15 Water Yards 6 Hafirs
A total of 264 water points repaired, upgraded or constructed.
Update Q4 2018.
Update Q4 2019.

title.narrative: Output 1: Inclusive mechanisms for IWRM are in place in targeted catchment areas
No. of approved catchment-level Water Resources Management Plans (including a hydrological analysis and identification of infrastructure to be developed)

comment.narrative: 13 catchment level WRMPs have been approved by the localities. 2 more plans have been developed/reviewed and are in the final stage to be approved by the locality.
Six Water Resources Management Plans have been approved. Three more Plans are ready for approval.

location.ref: Khor Arab, Dordeib, Hamesh Koreib, Butana, Qala en Nahal and Mahala.

comment.narrative: Update Q4 2018. 10 plans have been approved by locality, PCU and endorsed by other stakeholders. 5 more plan have been developed/reviewed and are in the final stage to be approved (North Delta, Subag, Wad Widayda,Tahaday and Adurut).

location.ref: Khor Arab, Hamesh Koreib, Dordeib, Butana, Qala en Hahal, Mahala, Darasta, Telkuk, Tawait, Al Saraf

comment.narrative: Update Q4 2019.
6 WRMP plans in process, reached at least step 4 of the 10-step process

title.narrative: Catchment-level Water Resources Management Committees functioning with active participation of nomadic pastoralists and women

comment.narrative:
In total, 15 WRMC’s are now officially in existence.
The participation of nomadic pastoralists, PWDs and women is taking place but at a different level. This depends on the prevalent cultural norms in the area. Partners continue to push for inclusiveness and a higher level of participation of all groups.
Update Q4 2018
Update Q4 2019.
